awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Efficient Methane-Hydrogen Separation on Metal Hydrides
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the potential development of a possibly safer and improved approach to hydrogen energy storage and separation from a hydrogen-methane gas mixture. Hydrogen has emerged as a promising potential alternative energy carrier to carbon-based fossil fuels due to its advantages including abundance, high energy density, and high conversion efficiency. It is necessary to develop a hydrogen economy as global oil and natural oil use are could be drastically reduced by 2050 to help address climate change. Hydrogen production, storage, and separation for end-use are critical challenges in developing a hydrogen economy. The standard gas storage method, which is to compress it under high pressure in a tank, can lead to perceived safety issues. A potential solution is to blend hydrogen with natural gas for specific uses and then separate it at the receiving site.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of a potentially safer transient hydrogen storage and high-density transport technology. This technology which may be a low-pressure, low-temperature storage and separation system could be integrated into the power, chemical, and transportation sectors to assist with reaching the decarbonization of global energy systems. Hydrogen is an energy carrier, but it is devoid of carbon; hence it has zero carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions from combustion. Multiple issues have been identified for hydrogen deployment including gas storage, transport, and delivery. One option is to repurpose the existing natural gas network where hydrogen gas could be mixed with natural gas in the desired ratio in a commercial pipeline and separated once at the destination. A class of metal hydrides and their alloys that are intermetallic compounds are known to undergo reversible hydrogen absorption/desorption reactions under controlled temperature and could form an efficient and highly selective Natural gas/Hydrogen separation system.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Recent interest in hydrogen, a carbonless molecule, is driven by the need to decarbonize power, transportation, heating and cooling, and other industrial processes by 2050 with a global market valuation of over $1 trillion. Such a system would require the integration of large-scale hydrogen in the energy sector. At present, the method and cost of large-scale hydrogen storage and subsequent separation for niche markets remains a challenge. The standard hydrogen storage method that involves compression to high pressure 10,000 psi (70 MPa) in a tank, would lead to perceived safety issues. The presented technology focuses on material-based hydrogen storage and separation built into one step that operates at ambient to low temperatures and 3-4 MPa. The proposed technology integrates large-scale hydrogen storage with on-demand pure hydrogen release under mild conditions. The team realizes that a cost-effective hydrogen storage and hydrogen-methane separation system would accelerate hydrogen in commercial systems.

We conducted over 110 interviews during “Customer Discovery” with NSF I-Corps funding. The interviews provided insight into both the technical issues as well as the process economics. Our key findings were: 1) The fact that the technology provides large-scale hydrogen storage and hydrogen-methane separation in one storage tank, is of interest to industry, 2) The technology offers lower Carbon Intensity option to store energy as hydrogen, 3) The identified early adopters are utilities and data centers, the latter for back-up green power, 4) The first adopters are likely utility providers who operate the existing gas grid networks and require hydrogen storage and separation to serve their customers. This technology allows utility providers to bypass constructing a natural gas pipeline system solely for hydrogen and seamlessly switch to renewable energy, 5) The attractiveness of lower cost and safer option (this technology) to high-pressure storage in tanks caught our attention during the customer interviews, 6) As the cost of storage and separation goes down, the decarbonization of disadvantaged communities would have a huge societal impact, 7) Overall, the conversations during interviews confirmed that this technology could solve a long-standing hydrogen storage and separation problem, bringing society one step closer to implementing the hydrogen economy.

However, the material lifetime and scale-up data are needed to accelerate commercialization of this technology.
